results.title: The Insulation story
results.creator_credit: Les Krizsan, Peter Katadotis and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Just as people need layers of clothing to keep warm, so houses need layers of padding to trap warm air and keep it inside as long as possible. The Insulation Story describes how you can get ready for a more comfortable winter with insulation, the not-so-magic formula. The film shows how much of the work can be done by the home-owner at reasonable cost.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Les Krizsan, Peter Katadotis and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Insider [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Michael Mann, Eric Roth, Spyglass Entertainment and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: From the opening scene, “The Insider” is a gripping and exhilarating thriller that investigates the corruption of journalist ethics. Russell Crowe gives an effective performance playing against type as Jeffrey Wigand, a paunchy middle-aged business man working for the tobacco industry who decides to blow the whistle on his colleagues’ attempts to hide the health risks associated with smoking. Al Pacino is the television journalist who takes on Jeffrey’s case but who finds that his own media executives refuse to support him. Based on the true story of when a tobacco industry whistleblower approached the US “Sixty Minutes” program, “The Insider” presents a cynical and disturbing case for how the increasing corporatisation of mass media leads to a denigration of the fifth estate’s objectivity and ethics. Michael Mann’s direction in this film is a critical leap for his own artistic career and the purpose and power of his vision is reflected in the high calibre of the support he receives from his cast and crew. The original music score is by Lisa Gerrard and Peter Bourke who are part of the musical group, Dead Can Dance. Cast also includes Christopher Plummer, Gina Gershon, Debi Mazer, Lindsay Crouse, Rip Torn and Philip Baker Hall.

results.title: The Inside story; Tiny Pod and Silverwings
results.brief_description: Two puppet plays which have been designed as a resource for use in drug education programs. Looks at the concept of self, responsibility for self, self confidence and self esteem. By promoting good health and encouraging responsibility for self, it is hoped that young people, if and when faced with the decision to abuse drugs, will have sufficient self confidence and self esteem to make a rational decision. Written and performed by the Skylark Puppet and Mask Theatre.

results.title: The Light beyond light & life; Using the telescope: astrophotography
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Infinity series”.
The human eye, even aided by powerful modern-day telescopes can only see a small fraction of the universe. This program shows how modern radio astronomy and computer imaging techniques have enabled us to see previously invisible objects, as well as more familiar ones, through the light of radio waves, ultra-violet, infra-red and x-rays. This episode of “Using the telescope” shows how a 4” and 8” telescope in conjunction with an SLR camera, and accessories can be used to take spectacular photographs.

results.title: The Innocents [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jack Clayton, Achilles Productions, Jack Clayton Productions and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A dark but brilliantly realised adaptation of Henry James’ gothic horror tale ‘Turn of the Screw’. A 19th century British governess (Deborah Kerr) arrives at a bleak mansion to take care of the wealthy household’s two children. Gradually, she begins to believe that there is a malevolent force in the children despite their beatific appearance. While Henry James’ novel leaves little doubt that they have been possessed by the demonic souls of the previous governess and her valet lover, who had died on the estate after an illicit sadomasochistic relationship, the film entertains the possibility that the supernatural events experienced by the governess are merely the product of her vivid imagination. Clayton cleverly uses startling imagery and nerve-bending sound to terrify the audience. Through its use of decor and lighting, and the impressive performances of Kerr and Michael Redgrave as the uncle, the film effectively conveys a claustrophobic sense of repressed hysteria. Cast also includes Megs Jenkins, Pamela Franklin, Martin Stephens and Peter Wyngarde. Also on VHS NTSC [315944].

results.title: The Queenslander: tales of the tropical north
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great train journeys of Australia”.
When you leave Brisbane on the Queenslander, you find yourself on an adventure that seems larger than life. It’s a glorious luxury holiday train, reminiscent of the exotic rail journeys of last century. And there’s plenty of time to be drawn into it. The journey takes the better part of two days, travelling over 1,000 miles up the tropical coast to Cairns in the far north of Queensland. Pass through lush forests, unusual peaks and tiny towns, pineapple and banana plantations, grazing cattle and miles of sugarcane. Meet travellers from all over the world, including young backpackers, families on holiday and wealthy tourists, each with their own perspective on the Australian experience.

results.title: The Trombone
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Anvil Film and Recording Group, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”
Alfred Flaszynski describes the history of the trombone, its development and the technique of playing, illustrated by excerpts from Ravel’s Bolero and George Lohmann’s Posaune Teufel. The problems of selecting each note by the correct use of the slide and the appropriate harmonic series are dealt with in detail.

results.title: The Ghan: a spiritual connection
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great train journeys of Australia”.
The legendary Ghan was named after the Afghans who with their camels opened the supply line through Australia’s interior. On this rich and fascinating journey from Adelaide to the Red Centre of Australia, traverse some of the world’s most ancient and inhospitable terrain, exploring the history of this great train line. At the remote town of Pimba, attend a rock concert in the middle of the Australian desert, arranged by the world music organisation WOMAD. Later, when the Ghan pulls into Alice Springs, visit Uluru, the largest free standing rock in the world. Uluru is a sacred aboriginal dreaming site that was returned to it’s original owners in 1985 and is now one of Australia’s most celebrated tourist attractions.
